functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: In what year did the CEOs of each of the top 5 global companies by revenue begin their term as CEO?
In what year did the CEOs of each of the top 5 global companies by revenue begin their term as CEO?

function.name: search
function.arguments: {"query": "List of current CEOs of the top 5 global companies by revenue"}

function.name: search
function.arguments: {"query": "List of current CEOs of the top 5 global companies by revenue"}

article_title: List of largest companies by revenue

![](image)Walmart has been the world's largest company by revenue since 2014.[1]
This list comprises the world's largest companies by consolidated revenue, according to the *Fortune* Global 500 2023 rankings and other sources.[2] American retail corporation Walmart has been the world's largest company by revenue since 2014.[1]


The list is limited to the top 50 companies, all of which have annual revenues exceeding US$130 billion. This list is incomplete, as not all companies disclose their information to the media and/or general public.[3]


Out of 50 largest companies 20 are American, 19 Asian and 11 European.[2]




## List[edit]


Information in the list relates to the most recent fiscal year (mostly FY 2022 or 2023)

msg.content:
No page with that title exists. Try searching for one of these similar articles instead:
- List of largest oil and gas companies by revenue
- List of telecommunications companies
- List of companies founded by Stanford University alumni
- Global Payments
- List of unicorn startup companies
- Alphabet Inc.
- Twitter, Inc.
- Lisa Su
- Eli Lilly and Company
- Bunge Global

msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Doug McMillon</title>
<fragment>
33. **^** Bryan, Bob (December 2, 2016). "Trump is forming an economic advisory team with the CEOs of Disney, General Motors, JPMorgan, and more". Business Insider. Retrieved June 1, 2017.
34. **^** Abrams, Rachel; Corkery, Michael (August 15, 2017). "Walmart's C.E.O. Joins Group to Rebuke Trump Over Charlottesville". *The New York Times*. Retrieved August 15, 2017.
35. **^** Sorkin, Andrew Ross (September 3, 2019). "Walmart's C.E.O. Steps Into the Gun Debate. Other C.E.O.s Should Follow". *The New York Times*. ISSN 0362-4331. Retrieved September 6, 2019.
36. **^** Doug McMillon - Are You Setting the Right Example at 0:47-0.58 in the video.

## External links[edit]


* ![flag](image)United States portal
* ![](image)Biography portal
* ![icon](image)Business and economics portal


* Official website ![Edit this at Wikidata](image)
* Appearances on C-SPAN




| Business positions
 |
| --- |
| Preceded byMike Duke
 |  **President of Walmart** 2013–present
 | **Incumbent** |


</fragment>
<fragment>

During McMillon's tenure, Walmart International's sales growth outpaced Walmart US[14] and grew to 29 percent of total sales company-wide.[9] When McMillon first became head of the division, it comprised more than 3,300 stores in 14 countries.[15] When Walmart announced it would move him to head Walmart Stores, Inc. in late 2013, Walmart International operated 6,300 stores in 26 countries.[16][*failed verification*]



### CEO of Walmart, Inc. (2014–present)[edit]


![](image)McMillon speaks from the White House Rose Garden on the COVID-19 pandemic in April 2020
Walmart announced on November 25, 2013, that McMillon would immediately join the company's board of directors,[17] and would replace Mike Duke as Walmart CEO effective on February 1, 2014, becoming the company's fifth chief executive.[4]


</fragment>
<fragment>

*Forbes* named McMillon to its World's Most Powerful People list in 2014, 2015 and 2016 where he ranked No. 29, No. 32, No. 27 respectively.[31] ExecRank ranked McMillon No. 4 on its 2015 list of top CEOs for large companies.[32]


In December 2016, McMillon joined a business forum assembled by then president-elect Donald Trump to provide strategic and policy advice on economic issues.[33] In August 2017, McMillon wrote a rebuke of President Trump's response to the violent protests Charlottesville, Virginia in an email to all employees and on the internal company website that is viewable by the public. The statement said the President, "missed a critical opportunity to help bring our country together". A company spokesman said McMillon would continue to serve on a presidential advisory council on economic development.[34]


</fragment>
<fragment>
26. **^** Wright, Maury (April 9, 2014). "Walmart plans major LED transition in supercenter lighting globally". *LEDs Magazine*. Retrieved February 16, 2016.
27. **^** Ellyatt, Holly (January 20, 2016). "Businesses can go green without going under". *CNBC*. Retrieved February 16, 2016.
28. ^ ***a*** ***b*** McGregor, Jena (April 1, 2015). "Wal-Mart CEO speaks out against 'religious freedom' bill in Arkansas". *The Washington Post*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.
29. **^** Alesci, Cristina; Isidore, Chris (June 23, 2015). "Walmart CEO: I was surprised we sold Confederate flags". *CNN*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.
30. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Smith, Aaron; Alesci, Cristina (August 26, 2015). "Walmart to stop selling AR-15s and similar guns". *CNN*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.
31. **^** "The world's most powerful people". *Forbes*. 2016. Retrieved March 4, 2017.
32. **^** Johnsen, Michael (December 17, 2015). "Rite Aid's John Standley names No. 1 mip-cap CEO". *Drug Store News*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.

</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** "Walmart Executive Management". Retrieved February 3, 2021.
2. **^** "Wal-Mart CEO bio box". Associated Press. February 17, 2016. Retrieved February 17, 2016 – via The Gazette.
3. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** Banjo, Shelly (November 25, 2013). "Wal-Mart taps veteran as new CEO". *The Wall Street Journal*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.
4. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** ***e*** ***f*** ***g*** ***h*** ***i*** ***j*** ***k*** O'Keefe, Brian (June 4, 2015). "The man who's reinventing Walmart". *Fortune*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.
5. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** Barr, Alistair; McCoy, Kevin (November 26, 2013). "New Wal-Mart CEO compares retail success to basketball". *USA Today*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.
6. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** "Doug McMillon's competitive spirit works well at Walmart". *USA Today*. April 18, 2010. Retrieved January 22, 2016.

</fragment>
</document>

31. **^** "The world's most powerful people". *Forbes*. 2016. Retrieved March 4, 2017.
32. **^** Johnsen, Michael (December 17, 2015). "Rite Aid's John Standley names No. 1 mip-cap CEO". *Drug Store News*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.

</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** "Walmart Executive Management". Retrieved February 3, 2021.
2. **^** "Wal-Mart CEO bio box". Associated Press. February 17, 2016. Retrieved February 17, 2016 – via The Gazette.
3. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** Banjo, Shelly (November 25, 2013). "Wal-Mart taps veteran as new CEO". *The Wall Street Journal*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.
4. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** ***e*** ***f*** ***g*** ***h*** ***i*** ***j*** ***k*** O'Keefe, Brian (June 4, 2015). "The man who's reinventing Walmart". *Fortune*. Retrieved January 22, 2016.

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Amin H. Nasser</title>
<content>
Saudi corporate executive



| Amin H. Nassar
 |
| --- |
| Nationality | Saudi |
| Alma mater | King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals |
| Occupation | Petroleum engineer |
| Title | President and chief executive officer of Saudi Aramco |
| Term | September 2015 - |
| Predecessor | Khalid A. Al Falih |
| Website | https://www.aramco.com/en |


**Amin Hassan Naser** (Arabic: أمين حسن الناصر‎) is the President and CEO of the Saudi Arabian oil company (Saudi Aramco), the world’s largest oil producer. He became acting president and chief executive in May 2015 before assuming the position permanently in September 2015.[1] During his tenure at Aramco, he has criticized fossil fuel divestment and promoted expansion and investment into oil production.[2][3]




## Education[edit]


Nasser holds a Bachelor's degree in petroleum engineering from the King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals in Dhahran. He completed the Saudi Aramco Management Development Seminar in Washington, D.C., in 1999; the Saudi Aramco Global Business Program in 2000; and the Senior Executive Program at Columbia University in 2002.[4]



## Career[edit]


Nasser began his career with Saudi Aramco in 1982 as an engineer in the oil production department and proceeded to work in drilling and reservoir management. In 1997, he became manager of the Ras Tanura Producing Department. Later he became manager of the Northern Area Production Engineering Department, as well as the Safaniya Aramco.com Offshore and Onshore Producing Departments.[5] He was appointed Chief Petroleum Engineer in 2004 and became Senior Vice President of Saudi Aramco’s Upstream operations in 2008.[6] Nasser became acting President and CEO of Aramco in May 2015, and was made permanent in September 2015.[1]


As CEO, he led the company’s response to drone and missile attacks on its facilities in September 2019.[7]


Prior to Aramco’s initial public offering (IPO), he led the company’s entry into the global debt and capital markets with its first bond issuance.[8] He oversaw Aramco’s 2019 IPO in which it became the world’s most valuable listed company, and led its 2020 acquisition of Saudi petrochemicals giant SABIC.[9][10]


In 2021, amid growing pressure for fossil fuel companies to become greener to contribute to climate change mitigation, Nasser warned countries against divesting in fossil fuels, arguing that it would cause inflation and cause unrest.[2]



## Other[edit]


Nasser is on the Society of Petroleum Engineers's Industry Advisory Council, the International Advisory Board (IAB) of the KFUPM, the Board of Trustees of the King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST),[11] the World Economic Forum’s International Business Council, the JPMorgan International Advisory Council, the MIT President CEO Advisory Board and the Board of BlackRock.[12]


In July 2020, he received the ICIS Kavaler Award, which recognizes outstanding achievement in petrochemicals.[13] Nasser ranked first on the Forbes Middle East’s list of top 100 CEOs in the region for 2020.[14]



## References[edit]


1. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Saudi Aramco Names Amin H. Nasser as President". *The Wall Street Journal*. 7 September 2015. Retrieved 22 September 2015.
2. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Saudi Aramco warns of 'social unrest' if fossil fuels ditched too quickly". *Financial Times*. 2021-12-06. Retrieved 2021-12-07.
3. **^** Dahan, Maha El; Georgy, Michael (2022-08-14). "Saudi Aramco's Amin Nasser: a homegrown engineer who reached the top". *Reuters*.
4. **^** "Leadership- Amin H. Nasser - President and chief executive officer of Saudi Aramco". *Aramco*.
5. **^** "Amin H. Nasser | AIME". *www.aimehq.org*. Retrieved 2018-02-22.
6. **^** "Profile: Amin al-Nasser, incoming CEO of oil giant Saudi Aramco". *Al Arabiya*. 2 May 2015. Retrieved 22 September 2015.
7. **^** "Aramco CEO Survives Drones, Outlasts Rival in Hairy IPO Year". *Bloomberg*. December 2, 2019.
8. **^** "The $100 Billion Man: Aramco CEO Delivers Record-Breaking Bond". *Bloomberg*. April 10, 2019.
9. **^** "Saudi Aramco becomes most valuable listed company in history". *The Guardian*. 11 December 2019.
10. **^** "Saudi Aramco completes $69 billion SABIC stake deal, extends schedule". *Reuters*. 17 June 2020.
11. **^** "Amin H. Nasser: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg". *www.bloomberg.com*. Retrieved 2018-03-07.
12. **^** Correspondent, Callum Jones (2023-07-18). "Aramco boss Amin Nasser joins BlackRock board". *The Times*. ISSN 0140-0460. Retrieved 2023-07-19.
13. **^** "Aramco CEO honored with Kavaler Award". *Arabnews.com*. 29 July 2020.
14. **^** "Saudi Aramco CEO tops Forbes ME's list of top 100 CEOs". *Al Arabiya English*. 2022-07-06. Retrieved 2023-08-30.

| Authority control databases ![Edit this at Wikidata](image)
 |
| --- |

 |
| National | * Germany
 |

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Andy Jassy</title>
<fragment>
19. **^** Novet, Jordan (April 7, 2016). "Andy Jassy is finally named CEO of Amazon Web Services". VentureBeat. Archived from the original on February 3, 2021. Retrieved October 12, 2017.
20. **^** Balakrishnan, Anita (April 12, 2017). "The most highly paid Amazon executive isn't the CEO — it's the head of cloud". CNBC. Retrieved October 12, 2017.
21. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN)". Retrieved July 26, 2020.
22. **^** "Notice of 2020 Annual Meeting of Shareholders & Proxy Statement" (PDF). May 22, 2020. Retrieved July 26, 2020.
23. **^** Hartmans, Avery (November 23, 2021). "Jeff Bezos surprised Andy Jassy by picking him as Amazon CEO: VF". *Business Insider*. Retrieved June 3, 2022.
24. **^** Palmer, Annie (July 5, 2022). "first year after succeeding Bezos as Amazon CEO". *CNBC*. Retrieved April 8, 2023.
25. **^** Thorbecke, Catherine (April 1, 2022). "Amazon CEO Andy Jassy's total compensation package topped $212 million". *CNN International*. Retrieved April 4, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>
|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| Current | * Jeff Bezos (Founder and Executive Chairman)
* Andy Jassy (President and CEO)
* Werner Vogels (CTO)
 |
| Former | * Rick Dalzell
* Paul Davis
* Tony Hsieh
* Christopher North
* Ram Shriram
* Tom Szkutak
* Brian Valentine
 |

 |
| Facilities | * List of Amazon locations
* Doppler
* Day 1
* *HQ2*
* Principal Place
* Spheres
* *Bellevue 600*
 |
| Products andservices | 


</fragment>
<fragment>

1. ^ ***a*** ***b*** McLaughlin, Kevin (August 4, 2015). "Andy Jassy: Amazon's $6 Billion Man". CRN. Archived from the original on February 3, 2021. Retrieved October 12, 2017.
2. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Andy Jassy: Amazon Web Services (AWS) CEO". *montgomerysummit*. Archived from the original on February 23, 2021. Retrieved February 2, 2021.
3. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** ***e*** ***f*** "Elana Caplan And Andrew Jassy". *The New York Times*. August 24, 1997. ISSN 0362-4331. Archived from the original on February 3, 2021. Retrieved February 2, 2021.
4. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Rao, Leena (June 28, 2015). "How Andy Jassy helped Amazon own the cloud". Fortune.com. Archived from the original on February 3, 2021. Retrieved February 23, 2021.
5. **^** "Andrew R Jassy from Seattle, WA". Nuwber. Archived from the original on February 2, 2021.
6. **^** "Andrew R. Jassy, MBA". 4-traders.
7. **^** Weise, Karen (February 2, 2021). "Jeff Bezos to Step Down as Amazon C.E.O." *The New York Times*.

</fragment>
<fragment>

Jassy joined Amazon as a marketing manager in 1997[13] with several other Harvard MBA colleagues.[17][15] In 2003, he and Jeff Bezos came up with the idea to create the cloud computing platform that became known as Amazon Web Services, which launched in 2006.[18] Jassy headed it and its team of 57 people.[1]



![](image)Jassy in 2016
In 2016, Jassy was named Person of the Year by the *Financial Times*.[15] A month later, Jassy was promoted from senior vice president to chief executive officer of Amazon Web Services.[19][16] That year Jassy earned $36.6 million.[20]


</fragment>
<fragment>

For his work as chief executive officer of Amazon Web Services, Jassy earned a base compensation of $175,000 in 2020, plus a restricted stock unit award of 4,023 shares (a value of $12,104,844.93 as of July 26, 2020[21]) of Amazon with vesting beginning in 2023. He also received a restricted stock unit award in April 2018 for 10,000 shares (a value of $30,089,100 as of July 26, 2020),[21] which vest 37.5% in 2021, 12.5% in 2022, 37.5% in 2023, and 12.5% in 2024.[22]


In January 2021, Bezos designated Jassy his official successor as CEO;[23] with the transition occurring on July 5, 2021.[24] As CEO of Amazon, Jassy received a ten year pay package totaling $212.7 million. The majority of the compensation package is in stock and vests over 10 years.[25]



## Personal life[edit]


</fragment>
</document>

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Russell Hardy</title>
<content>
British businessman







| Russell Hardy
 |
| --- |
| Nationality | British |
| Education | Imperial College London |
| Occupation | Oil trader |
| Title | CEO, Vitol |
| Term | March 2018- |
| Predecessor | Ian Taylor |


**Russell Hardy** is a British businessman, and the chief executive (CEO) of Vitol, the world's largest independent oil trading company.[1]



## Early life[edit]


Hardy has a master's degree in engineering from Imperial College London.[2][3]



## Career[edit]


Hardy began his career working for BP, trading fuel oil.[2]


In 1993, Hardy left BP and joined Vitol.[3] He has been a member of its executive committee since 2007, and CEO of the Europe, Middle-East and Africa region since 2017.[2] In March 2018, he was appointed CEO of the entire company, succeeding Ian Taylor, who became chairman.[2][4]


In 2022, Hardy predicted that Russia won't be able to protect itself from the negative effects of the Western sanctions, while Russian oil export would fall to 1 million barrels a day in winter 2022-2023.[5][6]



## References[edit]


1. **^** Rathenow, Solveig (3 November 2022). "Die wachsende "Schattenflotte" an Tankern wird den Einbruch von Russlands Ölexporten nicht abfedern, sagt ein Experte". *Business Insider* (in German). Retrieved 10 November 2022.
2. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** Payne, Julia. "Hardy takes helm from Taylor as CEO of trading giant Vitol". *reuters.com*. Retrieved 8 November 2018.
3. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Russell Hardy - Gastech Exhibition & Conference". *gastechevent.com*. Retrieved 8 November 2018.
4. **^** "Top Trader Vitol Has New CEO as Taylor Becomes Chairman". *www.bloomberg.com*. 15 March 2018. Retrieved 8 November 2018.
5. **^** Rathenow, Solveig (3 November 2022). "Die wachsende "Schattenflotte" an Tankern wird den Einbruch von Russlands Ölexporten nicht abfedern, sagt ein Experte". *Business Insider* (in German). Retrieved 10 November 2022.
6. **^** "Ukraine-Blog: Fotos, Fakes und Fragen – «Unsere Kommandanten nennen Menschen Fleisch»: Russische Infanteristen sind wütend und beschweren sich". *Basler Zeitung* (in German). Retrieved 10 November 2022.

  




|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| ![Stub icon](image) | This United Kingdom business-related biographical article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. |

* v
* t
* e

</content>
</document>

msg.content:
Here is the information I found on the individuals you asked about:

### Doug McMillon
- **Position**: President and CEO of Walmart Inc. since 2014.
- **Career Highlights**:
  - Joined Walmart's board of directors in 2013.
  - Previously led Walmart International, where sales growth outpaced Walmart US.
  - Named to Forbes' World's Most Powerful People list in 2014, 2015, and 2016.
  - Joined a business forum assembled by then-president-elect Donald Trump in 2016.
  - Publicly rebuked President Trump's response to the Charlottesville protests in 2017.

### Amin H. Nasser
- **Position**: President and CEO of Saudi Aramco since September 2015.
- **Career Highlights**:
  - Joined Saudi Aramco in 1982 and held various positions in drilling and reservoir management.
  - Became Chief Petroleum Engineer in 2004 and Senior Vice President of Upstream operations in 2008.
  - Led the company through its response to drone and missile attacks in 2019.
  - Oversaw Aramco's IPO in 2019, making it the world's most valuable listed company.
  - Advocated against rapid fossil fuel divestment, warning of potential social unrest and inflation.

### Andy Jassy
- **Position**: President and CEO of Amazon since July 5, 2021.
- **Career Highlights**:
  - Joined Amazon in 1997 as a marketing manager.
  - Co-created Amazon Web Services (AWS) with Jeff Bezos, launching it in 2006.
  - Named CEO of AWS in 2016.
  - Designated by Jeff Bezos as his successor in January 2021.
  - Received a ten-year pay package totaling $212.7 million as CEO of Amazon.

### Russell Hardy
- **Position**: CEO of Vitol since March 2018.
- **Career Highlights**:
  - Holds a master's degree in engineering from Imperial College London.
  - Began his career at BP, trading fuel oil.
  - Joined Vitol in 1993 and has been a member of its executive committee since 2007.
  - Predicted in 2022 that Russia would struggle to mitigate the effects of Western sanctions on its oil exports.

### Xin Baoan

### Doug McMillon
- **Position**: President and CEO of Walmart Inc. since 2014.
- **Career Highlights**:
  - Joined Walmart's board of directors in 2013.
  - Previously led Walmart International, where sales growth outpaced Walmart US.
  - Named to Forbes' World's Most Powerful People list in 2014, 2015, and 2016.
  - Joined a business forum assembled by then-president-elect Donald Trump in 2016.
  - Publicly rebuked President Trump's response to the Charlottesville protests in 2017.

### Amin H. Nasser
- **Position**: President and CEO of Saudi Aramco since September 2015.
- **Career Highlights**:
  - Joined Saudi Aramco in 1982 and held various positions in drilling and reservoir management.
  - Became Chief Petroleum Engineer in 2004 and Senior Vice President of Upstream operations in 2008.
  - Led the company through its response to drone and missile attacks in 2019.
  - Oversaw Aramco's IPO in 2019, making it the world's most valuable listed company.
  - Advocated against rapid fossil fuel divestment, warning of potential social unrest and inflation.

### Andy Jassy
- **Position**: President and CEO of Amazon since July 5, 2021.
- **Career Highlights**:
  - Joined Amazon in 1997 as a marketing manager.
  - Co-created Amazon Web Services (AWS) with Jeff Bezos, launching it in 2006.
  - Named CEO of AWS in 2016.
  - Designated by Jeff Bezos as his successor in January 2021.
  - Received a ten-year pay package totaling $212.7 million as CEO of Amazon.

### Russell Hardy
- **Position**: CEO of Vitol since March 2018.
- **Career Highlights**:
  - Holds a master's degree in engineering from Imperial College London.
  - Began his career at BP, trading fuel oil.
  - Joined Vitol in 1993 and has been a member of its executive committee since 2007.
  - Predicted in 2022 that Russia would struggle to mitigate the effects of Western sanctions on its oil exports.
